Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
we're used to dividing how people vote in elections according to the categories of right wing and left wing but there might be another way of labeling an electorate that taps into something broader and deeper in human personality we might apportion people into the camps of romantic and classical voters which one might you be part of here is some of what separates these two fundamental electoral types romantic believes that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken if we entered an agreement or scrapped an agreement started a war or ended a war the romantic considers a degree of impatience to be a vital resource in governing a nation they may not think too badly of a bit of anger either so long as it's handled correctly you can be too forgiving after all the romantic is excited by how things might ideally be and always judges what currently exists in the world by the standard of a better imagined alternative most of the time the current state of things arouses them to intense disappointment as they consider the injustice a--'s prevarications compromises and timidity of almost everyone in government for their part the classical voter is highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions they pay special attention to what can go wrong they're very concerned to mitigate the downside they're aware that most things could be a lot worse before condemning a policy they consider the standard of policy across history and may regard a current arrangement as bearable under the circumstances their view of people is fundamentally rather dark they believe that everyone is probably slightly worse than they seem they feel humans have deeply dangerous impulses lusts and drives and believe that the task of politics is to try and contain them rather than liberate genius strength beauty or benevolence high ideals make them nervous they are led by a desire not to make anything worse insofar as they hope for improvement it's in a cautious modest way they dare to suppose that the world may be a marginally better place in about 300 years time romantics see a lot that's wrong with the world and feel confident about analyzing who might be to blame for it perhaps this particular social group or that class a problem can't just be no one's fault and therefore the task of politics is to identify the wrongdoers and respond appropriately romantics feel a basic trust in their own capacity for purity they are sure they would be unable to be as shabby as their enemies whom they can therefore attack with a relatively clean conscience classical voters also notice what's wrong but they're highly aware of their own capacity for sinfulness and error which makes them hesitant about apportioning blame they recognize how easily they might have been active wrongdoers if circumstances have been different and suppose that no one has a monopoly on righteousness they would suggest that evil is pretty proportionately distributed across all groups and classes and that a priority is therefore for us to tolerantly cut each other slack at every turn romantic voters believe that everything great in history is the result of talented individuals taking destiny into their hands and struggling against the inertia and conservatism of the mass and most importantly of institutions classical voters are deeply worried by the possibility of lone actors taking matters into their hands and through natural weaknesses which all of us even the most intelligent are afflicted by creating disaster they are therefore on the side of legally grounded extremely slow-moving institutions that are designed to restrain individual power and contain the capacity of any one person to shift the direction of the group to quickly romantic voters believe it's possible to understand a situational issue so clearly one can be sure of complete justice and rightness vertol those who don't agree don't have to be listened to politely they are evidently wrong and can be silenced or sidelined as required classical voters are extremely alert to the possibility of error in their own and others analyses of policy but they are therefore committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views in which they suspect a portion of the truth may always be lodged [Music] romantic voters feel that the best way for a nation to be safe in the world is for it to seem prominently strong classical voters feel that the best way to be safe in the world is to be thought well of and will therefore avoid actions that could upset alarm or confuse neighbors they're aware of how easily strength arouses the desire of others to be equally strong back they suspect the best way to proceed might be to train and private for the worst but extend a hand of friendship at every public turn both romantic and classical political orientations have important truths to impart neither is wholly right or wrong they need to be balanced and none of us are in any case ever simply one or the other but because a good political landscape requires a judicious balance of throath temperaments at this point in history in many countries it might be the classical electoral attitude whose distinctive claims and wisdom we need to listen to most intently and which is most ripe for rediscovery you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between the two electoral types described in this video, which believes that impatience is a vital resource for governing a nation?
Options: A. Romantic voter, B. Classical voter
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What two fundamental electoral types are proposed as an alternative to the traditional left-wing and right-wing categories? Options: A. Liberal and Conservative, B. Romantic and Classical, C. Democratic and Republican, D. Socialist and Capitalist Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is a key characteristic of Romantic voters in terms of their approach to change? Options: A. They are highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions., B. They believe that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken., C. They are committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views., D. They prioritize maintaining the status quo. Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do Classical voters approach the idea of improvement in the world? Options: A. They hope for rapid and radical change., B. They dare to suppose that the world may be a marginally better place in about 300 years time., C. They believe that everything great in history is the result of talented individuals taking destiny into their hands., D. They think that high ideals are the key to progress. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a key difference between Romantic and Classical voters in terms of their views on human nature? Options: A. Romantic voters believe that humans are inherently good, while Classical voters believe that humans are inherently bad., B. Romantic voters believe that humans have the potential for greatness, while Classical voters believe that humans have deeply dangerous impulses and drives., C. Romantic voters believe that humans are rational, while Classical voters believe that humans are emotional., D. Romantic voters believe that humans are fixed, while Classical voters believe humans are malleable. Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, how do Romantic voters typically assign blame in politics? Options: A. They blame systemic failures rather than individuals., B. They blame individuals or groups for problems and believe they should be held accountable., C. They blame external circumstances rather than individuals or systems., D. They blame a lack of resources rather than individuals or systems. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a key characteristic of Classical voters in terms of their approach to decision-making? Options: A. They are impulsive and action-oriented., B. They are cautious and hesitant to take bold action., C. They are analytical and data-driven., D. They are intuitive and rely on instinct. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How do Romantic voters view the role of institutions in politics? Options: A. They believe that institutions are necessary to restrain individual power and contain the capacity for error., B. They believe that institutions are obstacles to progress and that individuals should be free to take bold action., C. They believe that institutions are neutral and that their role is to implement the will of the people., D. They believe that institutions are corrupt and that they need to be overhauled. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key difference between Romantic and Classical voters in terms of their views on national security? Options: A. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize military strength, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize diplomacy and being thought well of by other nations., B. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize economic security, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize environmental security., C. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize individual freedom, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize collective security., D. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize being thought well of by other nations, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize being strong. Correct Option: A
Question 9: How do Classical voters approach the idea of dissenting views in politics? Options: A. They believe that dissenting views should be silenced or sidelined., B. They believe that dissenting views should be tolerated and heard., C. They believe that dissenting views should be ignored., D. They believe that dissenting views should be ridiculed. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the current state of the balance between Romantic and Classical electoral attitudes in many countries? Options: A. The Romantic attitude is dominant and needs to be balanced by a greater emphasis on Classical values., B. The Classical attitude is dominant and needs to be balanced by a greater emphasis on Romantic values., C. The two attitudes are currently in balance and no adjustment is needed., D. The transcript does not mention the current state of the balance between the two attitudes. Correct Option: A
Question 11: What do Romantic voters believe is the primary driver of great achievements in history? Options: A. Talented individuals taking destiny into their hands., B. Institutions and collective efforts., C. Economic and social structures., D. Chance and circumstance. Correct Option: A
Question 12: How do Classical voters view the potential for error in their own and others' analyses of policy? Options: A. They are extremely alert to the possibility of error and therefore committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views., B. They are confident in their own abilities and therefore dismissive of dissenting views., C. They are neutral and open to different perspectives., D. They are overly critical and therefore hesitant to make decisions. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content, as both questions aim to distinguish between the characteristics of Romantic and Classical voters. Although the options are not identical, the correct option in Question 2 (Option B) directly relates to the characteristic of Romantic voters mentioned in the ground truth MCQ, which is their belief in the importance of bold and swift action, implying that impatience is a vital resource for governing a nation.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Classical voters believe that the state of the world could be better...
Options: A. tomorrow, B. by the end of a politician's term, C. in 300 years
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What two fundamental electoral types are proposed as an alternative to the traditional left-wing and right-wing categories? Options: A. Liberal and Conservative, B. Romantic and Classical, C. Democratic and Republican, D. Socialist and Capitalist Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is a key characteristic of Romantic voters in terms of their approach to change? Options: A. They are highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions., B. They believe that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken., C. They are committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views., D. They prioritize maintaining the status quo. Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do Classical voters approach the idea of improvement in the world? Options: A. They hope for rapid and radical change., B. They dare to suppose that the world may be a marginally better place in about 300 years time., C. They believe that everything great in history is the result of talented individuals taking destiny into their hands., D. They think that high ideals are the key to progress. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a key difference between Romantic and Classical voters in terms of their views on human nature? Options: A. Romantic voters believe that humans are inherently good, while Classical voters believe that humans are inherently bad., B. Romantic voters believe that humans have the potential for greatness, while Classical voters believe that humans have deeply dangerous impulses and drives., C. Romantic voters believe that humans are rational, while Classical voters believe that humans are emotional., D. Romantic voters believe that humans are fixed, while Classical voters believe humans are malleable. Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, how do Romantic voters typically assign blame in politics? Options: A. They blame systemic failures rather than individuals., B. They blame individuals or groups for problems and believe they should be held accountable., C. They blame external circumstances rather than individuals or systems., D. They blame a lack of resources rather than individuals or systems. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a key characteristic of Classical voters in terms of their approach to decision-making? Options: A. They are impulsive and action-oriented., B. They are cautious and hesitant to take bold action., C. They are analytical and data-driven., D. They are intuitive and rely on instinct. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How do Romantic voters view the role of institutions in politics? Options: A. They believe that institutions are necessary to restrain individual power and contain the capacity for error., B. They believe that institutions are obstacles to progress and that individuals should be free to take bold action., C. They believe that institutions are neutral and that their role is to implement the will of the people., D. They believe that institutions are corrupt and that they need to be overhauled. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key difference between Romantic and Classical voters in terms of their views on national security? Options: A. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize military strength, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize diplomacy and being thought well of by other nations., B. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize economic security, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize environmental security., C. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize individual freedom, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize collective security., D. Romantic voters believe that a nation should prioritize being thought well of by other nations, while Classical voters believe that a nation should prioritize being strong. Correct Option: A
Question 9: How do Classical voters approach the idea of dissenting views in politics? Options: A. They believe that dissenting views should be silenced or sidelined., B. They believe that dissenting views should be tolerated and heard., C. They believe that dissenting views should be ignored., D. They believe that dissenting views should be ridiculed. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the current state of the balance between Romantic and Classical electoral attitudes in many countries? Options: A. The Romantic attitude is dominant and needs to be balanced by a greater emphasis on Classical values., B. The Classical attitude is dominant and needs to be balanced by a greater emphasis on Romantic values., C. The two attitudes are currently in balance and no adjustment is needed., D. The transcript does not mention the current state of the balance between the two attitudes. Correct Option: A
Question 11: What do Romantic voters believe is the primary driver of great achievements in history? Options: A. Talented individuals taking destiny into their hands., B. Institutions and collective efforts., C. Economic and social structures., D. Chance and circumstance. Correct Option: A
Question 12: How do Classical voters view the potential for error in their own and others' analyses of policy? Options: A. They are extremely alert to the possibility of error and therefore committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views., B. They are confident in their own abilities and therefore dismissive of dissenting views., C. They are neutral and open to different perspectives., D. They are overly critical and therefore hesitant to make decisions. Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
we're used to dividing how people vote in elections according to the categories of right wing and left wing but there might be another way of labeling an electorate that taps into something broader and deeper in human personality we might apportion people into the camps of romantic and classical voters which one might you be part of here is some of what separates these two fundamental electoral types romantic believes that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken if we entered an agreement or scrapped an agreement started a war or ended a war the romantic considers a degree of impatience to be a vital resource in governing a nation they may not think too badly of a bit of anger either so long as it's handled correctly you can be too forgiving after all the romantic is excited by how things might ideally be and always judges what currently exists in the world by the standard of a better imagined alternative most of the time the current state of things arouses them to intense disappointment as they consider the injustice a--'s prevarications compromises and timidity of almost everyone in government for their part the classical voter is highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions they pay special attention to what can go wrong they're very concerned to mitigate the downside they're aware that most things could be a lot worse before condemning a policy they consider the standard of policy across history and may regard a current arrangement as bearable under the circumstances their view of people is fundamentally rather dark they believe that everyone is probably slightly worse than they seem they feel humans have deeply dangerous impulses lusts and drives and believe that the task of politics is Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
So a few years ago, I did something really brave, or some would say really stupid. I ran for Congress. For years, I had existed
safely behind the scenes in politics as a fundraiser, as an organizer, but in my heart, I always wanted to run. The sitting congresswoman
had been in my district since 1992. She had never lost a race, and no one had really even run against her
in a Democratic primary. But in my mind, this was my way to make a difference, to disrupt the status quo. The polls, however,
told a very different story. My pollsters told me
that I was crazy to run, that there was no way that I could win. But I ran anyway, and in 2012, I became an upstart
in a New York City congressional race. I swore I was going to win. I had the endorsement
from the New York Daily News, the Wall Street Journal
snapped pictures of me on election day, and CNBC called it one of the hottest
races in the country. I raised money from everyone I knew, including Indian aunties that were just so happy
an Indian girl was running. But on election day, the polls were right, and I only got 19 percent of the vote, and the same papers
that said I was a rising political star now said I wasted 1.3 million dollars on 6,321 votes. Don't do the math. It was humiliating. Now, before you get the wrong idea, this is not a talk
about the importance of failure. Nor is it about leaning in. I tell you the story
of how I ran for Congress because I was 33 years old and it was the first time
in my entire life that I had done something
that was truly brave, where I didn't worry about being perfect. And I'm not alone: so many women I talk to tell me that they gravitate
towards careers and professions that they know
they're going to be great in, that they know they're
going to be perfect in, and it's no wonder why. Most girls are taught
to avoid risk and failure. We're taught to smile pretty, play it safe, get all A's. Boys, on the other hand, are taught to play rough, swing high, crawl to the top of the monkey bars
and then just jump off headfirst. And by the time they're adults, whether they're negotiating a raise
or even asking someone out on a date, they're habituated
to take risk after risk. They're rewarded for it. It's often said in Silicon Valley, no one even takes you seriously
unless you've had two failed start-ups. In other words, we're raising our girls to be perfect, and we're raising our boys to be brave. Some people worry
about our federal deficit, but I, I worry about our bravery deficit. Our economy, our society,
we're just losing out because we're not raising
our girls to be brave. The bravery deficit is why
women are underrepresented in STEM, in C-suites, in boardrooms, in Congress, and pretty much everywhere you look. In the 1980s, psychologist Carol Dweck looked at how bright fifth graders
handled an assignment that was too difficult for them. She found that bright girls
were quick to give up. The higher the IQ,
the more likely they were to give up. Bright boys, on the other hand, found the difficult material
to be a challenge. They found it energizing. They were more likely
to redouble their efforts. What's going on? Well, at the fifth grade level, girls routinely outperform boys
in every subject, including math and science, so it's not a question of ability. The difference is in how boys
and girls approach a challenge. And it doesn't just end in fifth grade. An HP report found
that men will apply for a job if they meet only 60 percent
of the qualifications, but women, women will apply only if they meet 100 percent
of the qualifications. 100 percent. This study is usually invoked
as evidence that, well, women need a little more confidence. But I think it's evidence that women have been socialized
to aspire to perfection, and they're overly cautious. (Applause) And even when we're ambitious, even when we're leaning in, that socialization of perfection has caused us to take
less risks in our careers. And so those 600,000 jobs
that are open right now in computing and tech, women are being left behind, and it means our economy
is being left behind on all the innovation and problems
women would solve if they were socialized to be brave instead of socialized to be perfect. (Applause) So in 2012, I started a company
to teach girls to code, and what I found
is that by teaching them to code I had socialized them to be brave. Coding, it's an endless process
of trial and error, of trying to get the right command
in the right place, with sometimes just a semicolon making the difference
between success and failure. Code breaks and then it falls apart, and it often takes many, many tries until that magical moment when what you're trying
to build comes to life. It requires perseverance. It requires imperfection. We immediately see in our program our girls' fear of not getting it right, of not being perfect. Every Girls Who Code teacher
tells me the same story. During the first week,
when the girls are learning how to code, a student will call her over
and she'll say, "I don't know what code to write." The teacher will look at her screen, and she'll see a blank text editor. If she didn't know any better,
she'd think that her student spent the past 20 minutes
just staring at the screen. But if she presses undo a few times, she'll see that her student
wrote code and then deleted it. She tried, she came close, but she didn't get it exactly right. Instead of showing
the progress that she made, she'd rather show nothing at all. Perfection or bust. It turns out that our girls
are really good at coding, but it's not enough
just to teach them to code. My friend Lev Brie, who is a professor
at the University of Columbia and teaches intro to Java tells me about his office hours
with computer science students. When the guys are struggling
with an assignment, they'll come in and they'll say, "Professor, there's something
wrong with my code." The girls will come in and say, "Professor, there's something
wrong with me." We have to begin to undo
the socialization of perfection, but we've got to combine it
with building a sisterhood that lets girls know
that they are not alone. Because trying harder
is not going to fix a broken system. I can't tell you how many women tell me, "I'm afraid to raise my hand, I'm afraid to ask a question, because I don't want to be the only one who doesn't understand, the only one who is struggling. When we teach girls to be brave and we have a supportive network
cheering them on, they will build incredible things, and I see this every day. Take, for instance,
two of our high school students who built a game called Tampon Run -- yes, Tampon Run -- to fight against the menstruation taboo and sexism in gaming. Or the Syrian refugee who dared show her love
for her new country by building an app
to help Americans get to the polls. Or a 16-year-old girl
who built an algorithm to help detect whether a cancer
is benign or malignant in the off chance
that she can save her daddy's life because he has cancer. These are just
three examples of thousands, thousands of girls who have been
socialized to be imperfect, who have learned to keep trying,
who have learned perseverance. And whether they become coders or the next Hillary Clinton or Beyoncé, they will not defer their dreams. And those dreams have never been
more important for our country. For the American economy,
for any economy to grow, to truly innovate, we cannot leave behind
half our population. We have to socialize our girls
to be comfortable with imperfection, and we've got to do it now. We cannot wait for them
to learn how to be brave like I did when I was 33 years old. We have to teach them
to be brave in schools and early in their careers, when it has the most potential
to impact their lives and the lives of others, and we have to show them
that they will be loved and accepted not for being perfect but for being courageous. And so I need each of you
to tell every young woman you know -- your sister, your niece,
your employee, your colleague -- to be comfortable with imperfection, because when we teach
girls to be imperfect, and we help them leverage it, we will build a movement
of young women who are brave and who will build
a better world for themselves and for each and every one of us. Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. Chris Anderson: Reshma, thank you. It's such a powerful vision you have.
You have a vision. Tell me how it's going. How many girls
are involved now in your program? Reshma Saujani: Yeah.
So in 2012, we taught 20 girls. This year we'll teach 40,000
in all 50 states. (Applause) And that number is really powerful, because last year we only graduated
7,500 women in computer science. Like, the problem is so bad that we can make
that type of change quickly. CA: And you're working with some
of the companies in this room even, who are welcoming
graduates from your program? RS: Yeah, we have about 80 partners, from Twitter to Facebook to Adobe to IBM to Microsoft
to Pixar to Disney, I mean, every single company out there. And if you're not signed up,
I'm going to find you, because we need every single tech company to embed a Girls Who Code
classroom in their office. CA: And you have some stories
back from some of those companies that when you mix in more gender balance in the engineering teams,
good things happen. RS: Great things happen. I mean, I think that it's crazy to me
to think about the fact that right now 85 percent of all
consumer purchases are made by women. Women use social media at a rate
of 600 percent more than men. We own the Internet, and we should be building
the companies of tomorrow. And I think when companies
have diverse teams, and they have incredible women
that are part of their engineering teams, they build awesome things,
and we see it every day. CA: Reshma, you saw the reaction there.
You're doing incredibly important work. This whole community is cheering you on.
More power to you. Thank you. RS: Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Men will apply for a job if they meet __% of the qualifications, whereas women will apply for a job if they meet __% of the qualifications.
Options: A. 25/90, B. 45/85, C. 60/100
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What motivated Reshma Saujani to run for Congress despite the polls indicating she would lose? Options: A. She wanted to prove a point about the importance of failure., B. She wanted to disrupt the status quo and make a difference., C. She was seeking fame and recognition., D. She was trying to please her family and friends. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to Reshma Saujani, how are girls typically socialized, and how does this impact their behavior? Options: A. Girls are socialized to be competitive and aggressive, which leads to burnout., D. Girls are socialized to be nurturing and caring, which limits their career choices. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What did psychologist Carol Dweck find in her study of bright fifth graders? Options: A. Boys were more likely to give up when faced with a difficult assignment., B. Girls were more likely to give up when faced with a difficult assignment., C. Both boys and girls were equally likely to give up when faced with a difficult assignment., D. The study found no significant differences between boys and girls. Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to an HP report, what percentage of qualifications do men and women typically require before applying for a job? Options: A. Men require 100% of qualifications, while women require 60%., B. Men require 60% of qualifications, while women require 100%., C. Both men and women require 80% of qualifications., D. The report found no significant differences between men and women. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main goal of Reshma Saujani's company, Girls Who Code? Options: A. To teach girls to be perfect and avoid risks., B. To teach girls to be brave and take risks through coding., C. To teach girls to be more confident and assertive., D. To teach girls to be more nurturing and caring. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does Reshma Saujani's program, Girls Who Code, aim to address the bravery deficit in girls? Options: A. By teaching girls to code and emphasizing the importance of perfection., B. By teaching girls to code and encouraging them to take risks and be imperfect., C. By teaching girls to be more competitive and aggressive., D. By teaching girls to be more nurturing and caring. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the significance of the "Tampon Run" game built by two high school students in Reshma Saujani's program? Options: A. It demonstrates the importance of perfection in coding., B. It shows how girls can use coding to address social issues and challenge taboos., C. It highlights the limitations of coding in addressing real-world problems., D. It is an example of a failed project that did not achieve its goals. Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to Reshma Saujani, what is the impact of the bravery deficit on the economy and society? Options: A. It leads to more innovation and growth., B. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
So a few years ago, I did something really brave, or some would say really stupid. I ran for Congress. For years, I had existed
safely behind the scenes in politics as a fundraiser, as an organizer, but in my heart, I always wanted to run. The sitting congresswoman
had been in my district since 1992. She had never lost a race, and no one had really even run against her
in a Democratic primary. But in my mind, this was my way to make a difference, to disrupt the status quo. The polls, however,
told a very different story. My pollsters told me
that I was crazy to run, that there was no way that I could win. But I ran anyway, and in 2012, I became an upstart
in a New York City congressional race. I swore I was going to win. I had the endorsement
from the New York Daily News, the Wall Street Journal
snapped pictures of me on election day, and CNBC called it one of the hottest
races in the country. I raised money from everyone I knew, including Indian aunties that were just so happy
an Indian girl was running. But on election day, the polls were right, and I only got 19 percent of the vote, and the same papers
that said I was a rising political star now said I wasted 1.3 million dollars on 6,321 votes. Don't do the math. It was humiliating. Now, before you get the wrong idea, this is not a talk
about the importance of failure. Nor is it about leaning in. I tell you the story
of how I ran for Congress because I was 33 years old and it was the first time
in my entire life that I had done something
that was truly brave, where I didn't worry about being perfect. And I'm not alone: so many women I talk to tell me that they gravitate
towards careers and professions that they know
they're going to be great in, that they know they're
going to be perfect in, and it's no wonder why. Most girls are taught
to avoid risk and failure. We're taught to smile pretty, play it safe, get all A's. Boys, on the other hand, are taught to play rough, swing high, crawl to the top of the monkey bars
and then just jump off headfirst. And by the time they're adults, whether they're negotiating a raise
or even asking someone out on a date, they're habituated
to take risk after risk. They're rewarded for it. It's often said in Silicon Valley, no one even takes you seriously
unless you've had two failed start-ups. In other words, we're raising our girls to be perfect, and we're raising our boys to be brave. Some people worry
about our federal deficit, but I, I worry about our bravery deficit. Our economy, our society,
we're just losing out because we're not raising
our girls to be brave. The bravery deficit is why
women are underrepresented in STEM, in C-suites, in boardrooms, in Congress, and pretty much everywhere you look. In the 1980s, psychologist Carol Dweck looked at how bright fifth graders
handled an assignment that was too difficult for them. She found that bright girls
were quick to give up. The higher the IQ,
the more likely they were to give up. Bright boys, on the other hand, found the difficult material
to be a challenge. They found it energizing. They were more likely
to redouble their efforts. What's going on? Well, at the fifth grade level, girls routinely outperform boys
in every subject, including math and science, so it's not a question of ability. The difference is in how boys
and girls approach a challenge. And it doesn't just end in fifth grade. An HP report found
that men will apply for a job if they meet only 60 percent
of the qualifications, but women, women will apply only if they meet 100 percent
of the qualifications. 100 percent. This study is usually invoked
as evidence that, well, women need a little more confidence. But I think it's evidence that women have been socialized
to aspire to perfection, and they're overly cautious. (Applause) And even when we're ambitious, even when we're leaning in, that socialization of perfection has caused us to take
less risks in our careers. And so those 600,000 jobs
that are open right now in computing and tech, women are being left behind, and it means our economy
is being left behind on all the innovation and problems
women would solve if they were socialized to be brave instead of socialized to be perfect. (Applause) So in 2012, I started a company
to teach girls to code, and what I found
is that by teaching them to code I had socialized them to be brave. Coding, it's an endless process
of trial and error, of trying to get the right command
in the right place, with sometimes just a semicolon making the difference
between success and failure. Code breaks and then it falls apart, and it often takes many, many tries until that magical moment when what you're trying
to build comes to life. It requires perseverance. It requires imperfection. We immediately see in our program our girls' fear of not getting it right, of not being perfect. Every Girls Who Code teacher
tells me the same story. During the first week,
when the girls are learning how to code, a student will call her over
and she'll say, "I don't know what code to write." The teacher will look at her screen, and she'll see a blank text editor. If she didn't know any better,
she'd think that her student spent the past 20 minutes
just staring at the screen. But if she presses undo a few times, she'll see that her student
wrote code and then deleted it. She tried, she came close, but she didn't get it exactly right. Instead of showing
the progress that she made, she'd rather show nothing at all. Perfection or bust. It turns out that our girls
are really good at coding, but it's not enough
just to teach them to code. My friend Lev Brie, who is a professor
at the University of Columbia and teaches intro to Java tells me about his office hours
with computer science students. When the guys are struggling
with an assignment, they'll come in and they'll say, "Professor, there's something
wrong with my code." The girls will come in and say, "Professor, there's something
wrong with me." We have to begin to undo
the socialization of perfection, but we've got to combine it
with building a sisterhood that lets girls know
that they are not alone. Because trying harder
is not going to fix a broken system. I can't tell you how many women tell me, "I'm afraid to raise my hand, I'm afraid to ask a question, because I don't want to be the only one who doesn't understand, the only one who is struggling. When we teach girls to be brave and we have a supportive network
cheering them on, they will build incredible things, and I see this every day. Take, for instance,
two of our high school students who built a game called Tampon Run -- yes, Tampon Run -- to fight against the menstruation taboo and sexism in gaming. Or the Syrian refugee who dared show her love
for her new country by building an app
to help Americans get to the polls. Or a 16-year-old girl
who built an algorithm to help detect whether a cancer
is benign or malignant in the off chance
that she can save her daddy's life because he has cancer. These are just
three examples of thousands, thousands of girls who have been
socialized to be imperfect, who have learned to keep trying,
who have learned perseverance. And whether they become coders or the next Hillary Clinton or Beyoncé, they will not defer their dreams. And those dreams have never been
more important for our country. For the American economy,
for any economy to grow, to truly innovate, we cannot leave behind
half our population. We have to socialize our girls
to be comfortable with imperfection, and we've got to do it now. We cannot wait for them
to learn how to be brave like I did when I was 33 years old. We have to teach them
to be brave in schools and early in their careers, when it has the most potential
to impact their lives and the lives of others, and we have to show them
that they will be loved and accepted not for being perfect but for being courageous. And so I need each of you
to tell every young woman you know -- your sister, your niece,
your employee, your colleague -- to be comfortable with imperfection, because when we teach
girls to be imperfect, and we help them leverage it, we will build a movement
of young women who are brave and who will build
a better world for themselves and for each and every one of us. Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. Chris Anderson: Reshma, thank you. It's such a powerful vision you have.
You have a vision. Tell me how it's going. How many girls
are involved now in your program? Reshma Saujani: Yeah.
So in 2012, we taught 20 girls. This year we'll teach 40,000
in all 50 states. (Applause) And that number is really powerful, because last year we only graduated
7,500 women in computer science. Like, the problem is so bad that we can make
that type of change quickly. CA: And you're working with some
of the companies in this room even, who are welcoming
graduates from your program? RS: Yeah, we have about 80 partners, from Twitter to Facebook to Adobe to IBM to Microsoft
to Pixar to Disney, I mean, every single company out there. And if you're not signed up,
I'm going to find you, because we need every single tech company to embed a Girls Who Code
classroom in their office. CA: And you have some stories
back from some of those companies that when you mix in more gender balance in the engineering teams,
good things happen. RS: Great things happen. I mean, I think that it's crazy to me
to think about the fact that right now 85 percent of all
consumer purchases are made by women. Women use social media at a rate
of 600 percent more than men. We own the Internet, and we should be building
the companies of tomorrow. And I think when companies
have diverse teams, and they have incredible women
that are part of their engineering teams, they build awesome things,
and we see it every day. CA: Reshma, you saw the reaction there.
You're doing incredibly important work. This whole community is cheering you on.
More power to you. Thank you. RS: Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Men will apply for a job if they meet __% of the qualifications, whereas women will apply for a job if they meet __% of the qualifications.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since the dawn of humanity, an estimated 100.8 billion
people have lived and died, a number that increases by about
.8% of the world's population each year. What happens to all 
of those people's bodies after they die and will the planet eventually
run out of burial space? When a person's heart stops beating, the body passes through several
stages before it begins decomposing. Within minutes after death, the blood begins settling in
the lower-most parts of the body. Usually eight to twelve hours later, the skin in those areas is discolored
by livor mortis, or post-mortem stain. And while at the moment of death
the body's muscles relax completely in a condition called primary flaccidity, they stiffen about two to six hours later
in what's known as rigor mortis. This stiffening spreads 
through the muscles, and its speed can be affected by age,
gender, and the surrounding environment. The body also changes temperature, usually cooling off 
to match its environment. Next comes decomposition, the process by which bacteria and insects
break apart the body. Many factors affect 
the rate of decomposition. There is, however, a basic guide of the
effect of the environment on decompositon called Casper's Law. It says that if all other 
factors are equal, a body exposed to air decomposes twice
as fast as one immersed in water and eight times as fast 
as one buried in earth. Soil acidity also greatly 
affects bone preservation. High-acidity soils with 
a pH of less than 5.3 will rapidly decompose bone, whereas in a neutral or basic soil
with a pH of 7 or more, a skeleton can remain in relatively
good condition for centuries. Different cultures throughout history have
developed unique approaches to burials. As far back as 
the first Neanderthal burials, death was accompanied by rituals, like the positioning, coloring,
or decorating of corpses. Traditional Christian burials decorate
the body in dress, while in traditional Islam, a body is wrapped in a piece 
of ritual fabric with the face oriented toward Mecca. Traditional Hindus ceremonially burn
the body, and Zoroastrians, followers of one of the
oldest monotheistic religions, traditionally place bodies atop a tower
to expose them to the Sun and scavenging birds.` Before the Industrial Revolution,
burials were simple and accessible. These days, with suitable burial land
running out in high-population areas, purchasing private gravesites
can be costly, and many people can't afford
simple burials. Even cremation, the second most common
burial practice in the world, comes with a high cost. As for the question 
of running out of space, the issue isn't so much about total land
in the world as it is that large populations cluster
together within cities. Most of the big cities in the world may run out of suitable burial grounds
within a century. For London, it's even sooner. That may happen by 2035. So are there alternatives
to traditional burials that might help with the space issue? In some countries, skyscraper cemeteries
enable vertical burials. Some options focus on the body's
relationship with the environment. Promession, for example, freeze-dries
and pulverizes the body, creating a powder 
that can turn into compost when mixed with oxygen and water. There are also green burials that use
special materials, such as biodegradable caskets, urns that sprout trees, and burial suits that grow mushrooms. Eternal reefs take that concept
to the depths of the ocean using a mixture of ashes and cement
to create marine habitats for sea life. Death is an inevitable part
of the human condition, but how we treat bodies and burials
continues to evolve. We may each have different spiritual, religious, or practical approaches to dying, but the ever-increasing demand
for burial space might give us a push to be creative about where our bodies go
after the final stages of life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The number of people who have died increase to what percent of the world’s population every year?
Options: A. 10, B. 15, C. .8, D. 5
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of people who have lived and died since the dawn of humanity? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 50 billion, C. 100.8 billion, D. 1 trillion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What term describes the discoloration of the skin caused by blood settling in the lower-most parts of the body after death? Options: A. Rigor mortis, B. Livor mortis, C. Primary flaccidity, D. Decomposition Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Casper's Law, how much faster does a body exposed to air decompose compared to one buried in earth? Options: A. 2 times, B. 4 times, C. 6 times, D. 8 times Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the effect of high-acidity soils on bone preservation? Options: A. Bones are preserved for centuries, B. Bones decompose rapidly, C. Bones remain intact for a few years, D. Bones are unaffected Correct Option: B
Question 5: In traditional Hindu burials, what is done with the body? Options: A. It is wrapped in a piece of ritual fabric, B. It is decorated in dress, C. It is ceremonially burned, D. It is buried in earth Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is a major issue with burials in high-population areas? Options: A. Lack of suitable burial land, B. High cost of cremation, C. Limited access to burial sites, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is Promession, and how does it address the issue of burial space? Options: A. A type of green burial that uses biodegradable materials, B. A method of freeze-drying and pulverizing the body to create compost, C. A type of traditional burial that uses a special type of casket, D. A method of cremation that reduces the body to ashes Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the concept of Eternal Reefs, and how does it relate to burials? Options: A. A type of green burial that uses biodegradable materials, B. A method of creating marine habitats for sea life using a mixture of ashes and cement, C. A type of traditional burial that uses a special type of casket, D. A method of cremation that reduces the body to ashes Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can be inferred about the future of burial practices based on the relationship between population growth and burial space? Options: A. As the population grows, there will be more burial space available, B. As the population grows, burial practices will remain unchanged, C. As the population grows, there will be a need for alternative burial practices to address the lack of space, D. As the population grows, traditional burials will become more affordable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a benefit of green burials in terms of their impact on the environment? Options: A. They reduce the amount of land needed for burials, B. They increase the amount of greenhouse gas emissions, C. They contaminate soil and groundwater, D. They have no impact on the environment Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided set. However, Question 1 is the closest in terms of discussing the number of people who have lived and died, but it does not address the annual increase.

If I had to choose the most similar question based on the content and intent, I would say that none of the questions perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a possible match based on the topic of population and death rate.

A possible match could be Question 6, which discusses the issue of burial space in high-population areas. However, this question does not directly address the annual increase in the number of deaths.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: What term describes the discoloration of the skin caused by blood settling in the lower-most parts of the body after death? Options: A. Rigor mortis, B. Livor mortis, C. Primary flaccidity, D. Decomposition Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the term that describes the discoloration of the skin after death, and both have the same correct answer, "Livor mortis".

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **2**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since the dawn of humanity, an estimated 100.8 billion
people have lived and died, a number that increases by about
.8% of the world's population each year. What happens to all 
of those people's bodies after they die and will the planet eventually
run out of burial space? When a person's heart stops beating, the body passes through several
stages before it begins decomposing. Within minutes after death, the blood begins settling in
the lower-most parts of the body. Usually eight to twelve hours later, the skin in those areas is discolored
by livor mortis, or post-mortem stain. And while at the moment of death
the body's muscles relax completely in a condition called primary flaccidity, they stiffen about two to six hours later
in what's known as rigor mortis. This stiffening spreads 
through the muscles, and its speed can be affected by age,
gender, and the surrounding environment. The body also changes temperature, usually cooling off 
to match its environment. Next comes decomposition, the process by which bacteria and insects
break apart the body. Many factors affect 
the rate of decomposition. There is, however, a basic guide of the
effect of the environment on decompositon called Casper's Law. It says that if all other 
factors are equal, a body exposed to air decomposes twice
as fast as one immersed in water and eight times as fast 
as one buried in earth. Soil acidity also greatly 
affects bone preservation. High-acidity soils with 
a pH of less than 5.3 will rapidly decompose bone, whereas in a neutral or basic soil
with a pH of 7 or more, a skeleton can remain in relatively
good condition for centuries. Different cultures throughout history have
developed unique approaches to burials. As far back as 
the first Neanderthal burials, death was accompanied by rituals, like the positioning, coloring,
or decorating of corpses. Traditional Christian burials decorate
the body in dress, while in traditional Islam, a body is wrapped in a piece 
of ritual fabric with the face oriented toward Mecca. Traditional Hindus ceremonially burn
the body, and Zoroastrians, followers of one of the
oldest monotheistic religions, traditionally place bodies atop a tower
to expose them to the Sun and scavenging birds.` Before the Industrial Revolution,
burials were simple and accessible. These days, with suitable burial land
running out in high-population areas, purchasing private gravesites
can be costly, and many people can't afford
simple burials. Even cremation, the second most common
burial practice in the world, comes with a high cost. As for the question 
of running out of space, the issue isn't so much about total land
in the world as it is that large populations cluster
together within cities. Most of the big cities in the world may run out of suitable burial grounds
within a century. For London, it's even sooner. That may happen by 2035. So are there alternatives
to traditional burials that might help with the space issue? In some countries, skyscraper cemeteries
enable vertical burials. Some options focus on the body's
relationship with the environment. Promession, for example, freeze-dries
and pulverizes the body, creating a powder 
that can turn into compost when mixed with oxygen and water. There are also green burials that use
special materials, such as biodegradable caskets, urns that sprout trees, and burial suits that grow mushrooms. Eternal reefs take that concept
to the depths of the ocean using a mixture of ashes and cement
to create marine habitats for sea life. Death is an inevitable part
of the human condition, but how we treat bodies and burials
continues to evolve. We may each have different spiritual, religious, or practical approaches to dying, but the ever-increasing demand
for burial space might give us a push to be creative about where our bodies go
after the final stages of life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Based on the Casper's Law, a body decomposes in_____8 times as fast as in____.
Options: A. Water; air, B. Air; water, C. Air; soil, D. Soil; water
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of people who have lived and died since the dawn of humanity? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 50 billion, C. 100.8 billion, D. 1 trillion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What term describes the discoloration of the skin caused by blood settling in the lower-most parts of the body after death? Options: A. Rigor mortis, B. Livor mortis, C. Primary flaccidity, D. Decomposition Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to Casper's Law, how much faster does a body exposed to air decompose compared to one buried in earth? Options: A. 2 times, B. 4 times, C. 6 times, D. 8 times Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the effect of high-acidity soils on bone preservation? Options: A. Bones are preserved for centuries, B. Bones decompose rapidly, C. Bones remain intact for a few years, D. Bones are unaffected Correct Option: B
Question 5: In traditional Hindu burials, what is done with the body? Options: A. It is wrapped in a piece of ritual fabric, B. It is decorated in dress, C. It is ceremonially burned, D. It is buried in earth Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is a major issue with burials in high-population areas? Options: A. Lack of suitable burial land, B. High cost of cremation, C. Limited access to burial sites, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is Promession, and how does it address the issue of burial space? Options: A. A type of green burial that uses biodegradable materials, B. A method of freeze-drying and pulverizing the body to create compost, C. A type of traditional burial that uses a special type of casket, D. A method of cremation that reduces the body to ashes Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the concept of Eternal Reefs, and how does it relate to burials? Options: A. A type of green burial that uses biodegradable materials, B. A method of creating marine habitats for sea life using a mixture of ashes and cement, C. A type of traditional burial that uses a special type of casket, D. A method of cremation that reduces the body to ashes Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can be inferred about the future of burial practices based on the relationship between population growth and burial space? Options: A. As the population grows, there will be more burial space available, B. As the population grows, burial practices will remain unchanged, C. As the population grows, there will be a need for alternative burial practices to address the lack of space, D. As the population grows, traditional burials will become more affordable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a benefit of green burials in terms of their impact on the environment? Options: A. They reduce the amount of land needed for burials, B. They increase the amount of greenhouse gas emissions, C. They contaminate soil and groundwater, D. They have no impact on the environment Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Although the wording of the question is not identical, the content and intent of Question 3 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions reference Casper's Law and the comparison of decomposition rates between a body exposed to air and one buried in earth. The correct option in Question 3 (D. 8 times) also matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. Air; soil, which states that a body decomposes 8 times as fast in air as in soil).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since the dawn of humanity, an estimated 100.8 billion
people have lived and died, a number that increases by about
.8% of the world's population each year. What happens to all 
of those people's bodies after they die and will the planet eventually
run out of burial space? When a person's heart stops beating, the body passes through several
stages before it begins decomposing. Within minutes after death, the blood begins settling in
the lower-most parts of the body. Usually eight to twelve hours later, the skin in those areas is discolored
by livor mortis, or post-mortem stain. And while at the moment of death
the body's muscles relax completely in a condition called primary flaccidity, they stiffen about two to six hours later
in what's known as rigor mortis. This stiffening spreads 
through the muscles, and its speed can be affected by age,
gender, and the surrounding environment. The body also changes temperature, usually cooling off 
to match its environment. Next comes decomposition, the process by which bacteria and insects
break apart the body. Many factors affect 
the rate of decomposition. There is, however, a basic guide of the
effect of the environment on decompositon called Casper's Law. It says that if all other 
factors are equal, a body exposed to air decomposes twice
as fast as one immersed in water and eight times as fast 
as one buried in earth. Soil acidity also greatly 
affects bone preservation. High-acidity soils with 
a pH of less than 5.3 will rapidly decompose bone, whereas in a neutral or basic soil
with a pH of 7 or more, a skeleton can remain in relatively
good condition for centuries. Different cultures throughout history have
developed unique approaches to burials. As far back as 
the first Neanderthal burials, death was accompanied by rituals, like the positioning, coloring,
or decorating of corpses. Traditional Christian burials decorate
the body in dress, while in traditional Islam, a body is wrapped in a piece 
of ritual fabric with the face oriented toward Mecca. Traditional Hindus ceremonially burn
the body, and Zoroastrians, followers of one of the
oldest monotheistic religions, traditionally place bodies atop a tower
to expose them to the Sun and scavenging birds.` Before the Industrial Revolution,
burials were simple and accessible. These days, with suitable burial land
running out in high-population areas, purchasing private gravesites
can be costly, and many people can't afford
simple burials. Even cremation, the second most common
burial practice in the world, comes with a high cost. As for the question 
of running out of space, the issue isn't so much about total land
in the world as it is that large populations cluster
together within cities. Most of the big cities in the world may run out of suitable burial grounds
within a century. For London, it's even sooner. That may happen by 2035. So are there alternatives
to traditional burials that might help with the space issue? In some countries, skyscraper cemeteries
enable vertical burials. Some options focus on the body's
relationship with the environment. Promession, for example, freeze-dries
and pulverizes the body, creating a powder 
that can turn into compost when mixed with oxygen and water. There are also green burials that use
special materials, such as biodegradable caskets, urns that sprout trees, and burial suits that grow mushrooms. Eternal reefs take that concept
to the depths of the ocean using a mixture of ashes and cement
to create marine habitats for sea life. Death is an inevitable part
of the human condition, but how we treat bodies and burials
continues to evolve. We may each have different spiritual, religious, or practical approaches to dying, but the ever-increasing demand
for burial space might give us a push to be creative about where our bodies go
after the final stages of life.

Since the dawn of humanity, an estimated 100.8 billion
people have lived and died, a number that increases by about
.8% of the world's population each year. What happens to all 
of those people's bodies after they die and will the planet eventually
run out of burial space? When a person's heart stops beating, the body passes through several
stages before it begins decomposing. Within minutes after death, the blood begins settling in
the lower-most parts of the body. Usually eight to twelve hours later, the skin in those areas is discolored
by livor mortis, or post-mortem stain. And while at the moment of death
the body's muscles relax completely in a condition called primary flaccidity, they stiffen about two to six hours later
in what's known as rigor mortis. This stiffening spreads 
through the muscles, and its speed can be affected by age,
gender, and the surrounding environment. The body also changes temperature, usually cooling off 
to match its environment. Next comes decomposition, the process by which bacteria and insects
break apart the body. Many factors affect 
the rate of decomposition. There is, however, a basic guide of the
effect of the environment on decompositon called Casper's Law. It says that if all other 
factors are equal, a body exposed to air decomposes twice
as fast as one immersed in water and eight times as fast 
as one buried in earth. Soil acidity also greatly 
affects bone preservation. High-acidity soils with 
a pH of less than 5.3 will rapidly decompose bone, whereas in a neutral or basic soil
with a pH of 7 or more, a skeleton can remain in relatively
good condition for centuries. Different cultures throughout history have
developed unique approaches to burials. As far back as 
the first Neanderthal burials, death was accompanied by rituals, like the positioning, coloring,
or decorating of corpses. Traditional Christian burials decorate
the body in dress, while in traditional Islam, a body is wrapped in a piece 
of ritual fabric with the face oriented toward Mecca. Traditional Hindus ceremonially burn
the body, and Zoroastrians, followers of one of the
oldest monotheistic religions, traditionally place bodies atop a tower
to expose them to the Sun and scavenging birds.` Before the Industrial Revolution,
burials were simple and accessible. These days, with suitable burial land
running out in high-population areas, purchasing private gravesites
can be costly, and many people can't afford
simple burials. Even cremation, the second most common
burial practice in the world, comes with a high cost. As for the question 
of running out of space, the issue isn't so much about total land
in the world as it is that large populations cluster
together within cities. Most of the big cities in the world may run out of suitable burial grounds
within a century. For London, it's even sooner. That may happen by 2035. So are there alternatives

relationship with the environment. Promession, for example, freeze-dries
and pulverizes the body, creating a powder

after the final stages of life.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It begins with a bit of discomfort and soon becomes a pressing sensation
that's impossible to ignore. Finally, it's all you can think about, and out of sheer desperation, you go on a hunt for a bathroom
until "ahh." Humans should urinate at least
four to six times a day, but occasionally, the pressures of modern
life forces us to clench and hold it in. How bad is this habit,
and how long can our bodies withstand it? The answers lie in the workings
of the bladder, an oval pouch 
that sits inside the pelvis. Surrounding this structure 
are several other organs that together make up the whole
urinary system. Two kidneys, two ureters, two urethral sphincters, and a urethra. Constantly trickling down from the kidneys
is the yellowish liquid known as urine. The kidneys make urine from a mix
of water and the body's waste products, funneling the unwanted fluid
into two muscular tubes called ureters. These carry it downward into
the hollow organ known as the bladder. This organ's muscular wall is made of
tissue called detrusor muscle which relaxes as the bladder fills
allowing it to inflate like a balloon. As the bladder gets full, 
the detrusor contracts. The internal urethral sphincter
automatically and involuntarily opens, and the urine is released. Whooshing downwards, 
the fluid enters the urethra and stops short at the external
urethral sphincter. This works like a tap. When you want to delay urinating,
you keep the sphincter closed. When you want to release it,
you can voluntarily open the flood gates. But how do you sense 
your bladder's fullness so you know when to pee? Inside the layers of detrusor muscles
are millions of stretch receptors that get triggered as the bladder fills. They send signals along your nerves
to the sacral region in your spinal cord. A reflex signal travels back to
your bladder, making the detrusor muscle 
contract slightly and increasing the bladder's pressure
so you're aware that it's filling up. Simultaneously, the internal 
urethral sphincter opens. This is called the micturition reflex. The brain can counter it if it's not
a good time to urinate by sending another signal to contract
the external urethral sphincter. With about 150 to 200 milliliters of urine
inside of it, the bladder's muscular wall 
is stretched enough for you to sense 
that there's urine within. At about 400 to 500 milliliters,
the pressure becomes uncomfortable. The bladder can go on stretching,
but only to a point. Above 1,000 milliliters, it may burst. Most people would lose bladder
control before this happens, but in very rare cases, such as when as a person can't sense
the need to urinate, the pouch can rupture painfully
requiring surgery to fix. But under normal circumstances, your decision to urinate stops the brain's
signal to the external urethral sphincter, causing it to relax 
and the bladder to empty. The external urethral sphincter
is one of the muscles of the pelvic floor, and it provides support to the urethra
and bladder neck. It's lucky we have these 
pelvic floor muscles because placing pressure on the system
by coughing, sneezing, laughing, or jumping could cause bladder leakage. Instead, the pelvic floor muscles
keep the region sealed until you're ready to go. But holding it in for too long, forcing out your urine too fast, or urinating without proper
physical support may over time weaken or overwork
that muscular sling. That can lead to an overactive
pelvic floor, bladder pain, urgency, or urinary incontinence. So in the interest of long-term health, it's not a great habit to hold your pee. But in the short term, at least,
your body and brain have got you covered, so you can conveniently choose
your moment of sweet release.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The kidneys create a fluid called urine which is made up of:
Options: A. Digestive enzymes, B. Sugars and salts, C. Water and waste products, D. Water and enzymes
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the normal frequency of urination in humans? Options: A. 2-3 times a day, B. 4-6 times a day, C. 7-8 times a day, D. 10-12 times a day Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the role of the detrusor muscle in the bladder? Options: A. It contracts to release urine and relaxes to hold urine., B. It relaxes to release urine and contracts to hold urine., C. It relaxes as the bladder fills, allowing it to inflate, and contracts when the bladder is full., D. It has no role in the release or holding of urine. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What might be a long-term consequence of holding urine for extended periods? Options: A. Increased bladder capacity, B. Weakened or overworked pelvic floor muscles, C. Improved bladder control, D. Reduced urine production Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary function of the internal urethral sphincter? Options: A. To voluntarily control the release of urine, B. To involuntarily control the release of urine, C. To regulate the amount of urine produced by the kidneys, D. To filter waste products from the blood Correct Option: B
Question 5: At what volumes of urine does the bladder experience different levels of pressure? Options: A. 150-200 mL: uncomfortable, 400-500 mL: slight pressure, 1000 mL: bladder rupture, B. 150-200 mL: slight pressure, 400-500 mL: uncomfortable, 1000 mL: bladder rupture, C. 150-200 mL: bladder rupture, 400-500 mL: uncomfortable, 1000 mL: slight pressure, D. 150-200 mL: uncomfortable, 400-500 mL: bladder rupture, 1000 mL: slight pressure Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the reflex that helps sense the bladder's fullness and the need to urinate? Options: A. Micturition reflex, B. Urination reflex, C. Bladder reflex, D. Detrusor reflex Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the role of the pelvic floor muscles in the urinary system? Options: A. They provide support to the urethra and bladder neck, preventing leakage during physical activities., B. They regulate the amount of urine produced by the kidneys., C. They control the release of urine from the bladder., D. They filter waste products from the blood. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What might be a potential consequence of being unable to sense the need to urinate due to a medical condition? Options: A. Increased bladder capacity, B. Weakened or overworked pelvic floor muscles, C. Bladder rupture, D. Reduced urine production Correct Option: C
Question 9: Is holding urine for extended periods beneficial or detrimental to long-term health? Options: A. Beneficial, as it strengthens the pelvic floor muscles., B. Detrimental, as it may weaken or overwork the pelvic floor muscles., C. Neutral, as it has no impact on long-term health., D. Depends on individual circumstances. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the correct sequence of events during the process of urination? Options: A. The detrusor muscle contracts, the internal urethral sphincter opens, and the external urethral sphincter opens, allowing urine to exit the body., B. The detrusor muscle relaxes, the internal urethral sphincter closes, and the external urethral sphincter opens, allowing urine to exit the body., C. The detrusor muscle contracts, the internal urethral sphincter opens, and the external urethral sphincter closes, holding urine in the bladder., D. The detrusor muscle relaxes, the internal urethral sphincter opens, and the external urethral sphincter opens, allowing urine to exit the body. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.
